ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: This trip/course serves a valuable function, filling a hole in the curriculum: industrial forestry.
Awesome course, great professors. Great field visits. Go south, young forester.
Good trip, although it's a bit hard to stay interested in forestry operations all day for 5 days...it could be done in a bit shorter time frame
Getting to know my classmates better, and getting to see forest industry in action.
Trip was great and prep was just enough.
Meeting a variety of forestry professionals.
The field trip provides an invaluable opportunity to meet and learn from the southern forestry industry
The experience... So many positive moments wrapped up into such a short amount of time.

The field trips. It gave me the opportunity as an international student to learn about the Southern forestry and how different it is from New England and from my home country. It was a rich learning experience for me.

This course is all about hands-on and first-hand exposure. It was essential for me to take in conjunction with Intro to Silviculture and helped me understand how concepts from that course are applied in the real world. As a neophyte, this gave me the opportunity to see for the first time many of the operations we talked about in my other courses. I also appreciated how the professors balanced the kinds of stops we made on this field trip course - we visited places with many different silvicultural goals, and that was especially helpful for contextualizing what we'd learned.
We can learn real management in the South.
Mike Ferucci's enthusiasm

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: A little bit more down time - and a bit more forest ecology - and could have done without the tour of the biomass plant! - and no need to drive over to TX.

Trip was really great, but felt a little disorganized. It should not be the responsibility of the students to be worried about the food budget constantly. More attention should be paid to meal planning in advance of departure.
Staying in the woods would be better than staying in chain motels.
Fewer big hotels next to the highway.
Organizational hiccups were encountered, but it didn't ruin the trip.

While it's hard to say because it potentially implies more work, it would have been great to have one or two assigned readings (articles perhaps). It was good that we all broke off pieces of what we needed to learn and taught each other, but I still felt I was ill-prepared to discuss any of the other topics presented. It would have been nice to have one or two other articles recommended to me (as a group) that would have broadened what I felt comfortable discussing with those we met. This is difficult on the short timeline, though, I recognize.
non...

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Fine.
Both Mike and Ann were excellent.
Very available.
The instructors were very helpful in getting us to meet and interact with wood industries both small and large scale the South being the wood basket of the United States is known for.

Both instructors were very enthusiastic about answering questions. Sometimes a meaning was assumed and the response could be minorly abrasive, but both instructors were very keen on student understanding and experience and were always ready to answer questions with alacrity.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: I'm an MF and am interested in biomass, so this trip was helpful. I'd been to GA and NC and talked with foresters and industrial forest owners before. This trip expanded that exposure. The TX biomass facility was a great stop for me.
It was great getting to better understand the pine plantations of the South.

It provided me with a whole new perspective on how forestry is practiced.This fits well with my interest in forest resources management as the trip gave me the opportunity to witness some useful forest resources operations and management regimes of companies we visited.
This course is not required, but I felt it was essential for my own growth in this career path.
I can learn part of forest management in the US.
I think if you're interested in forestry operations on any level, you've got to see how it's done at the largest scale. fascinating to see those machines move

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Strongly encouraged for my degree, and I thought it would be fun and interesting.
See above.
Introduction to large scale plantation forestry in the south.
See above.
To learn more about forest management in the US.

I felt there were basic operations in the field that I was unfamiliar with and which thus disadvantaged me and my perceived competency. Plus, it is an institution within the institution, and it seemed like a great idea to take part in it.
I can learn real forest management system in the US.
to learn more about industrial forestry and to bond with the MFs

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Yes - it was a great trip.
absolutely
See above.
yes.
Yes.
Yes it did and more.
Yes.
It did well.
Yes

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: A significant part of the experience is getting to spend time with your classmates - and this was really wonderful.
yes
yes.
Yes.
Yes it did and more.
Yes.
I did.
yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: AdvantagesIt gave us the opportunity to know ourselves and to share what we learntDisadvantagesIts difficult coordinating group affairs and trying to cater for everyones needs.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Do some of the readings.
Take advantage of this opportunity.
Enjoy yourselves and learn from the experience.

If you are planning to do anything related to forestry, take this course! Either as a first year or second year - doesn't matter; just take it (though it does reinforce very nicely material learned during Intro to Silviculture).
Enjoy the South!
Take it if you're an MF or interested in commercial forestry
